title: Decision Making Study
description: Allais paradox with processing fluency manipulation and structured page ordering
instructions: You will be presented with various questions and scenarios. Please read each one carefully and provide your honest responses. There are no right or wrong answers - we are interested in your personal preferences and opinions.

fixed.title: Welcome
fixed.content: Welcome to our decision-making study. You will be asked to make investment choices and answer some survey questions. Please read each question carefully.

fixed.title: Investment Decision
fixed.content:
Imagine you are choosing between two investment options. Which investment would you choose?

Investment A:
100% chance of $1,000,000
You receive $1 million with certainty.

Investment B:
89% chance of $1M, 10% chance of $5M, 1% chance of $0
Lottery with multiple possible outcomes.

randomizable.title: Brand Preference
randomizable.content: Which brand do you prefer for everyday products?

randomizable.title: Weather Preference
randomizable.content: What type of weather do you prefer?

randomizable.title: Education Level
randomizable.content: What is your highest level of education? (Optional)

randomizable.title: Attention Check
randomizable.content:
Please solve this simple math problem:

15 + 27 = ?

constrained.title: Investment Decision
constrained.content:
Now consider this different scenario. Which investment would you choose?

Investment C:
89% chance of $0, 11% chance of $1,000,000
Lottery with a chance of receiving money.

Investment D:
90% chance of $0, 10% chance of $5,000,000
Different lottery with a chance of receiving money.

completionMessage: Thank you for participating in our study! This study tested the Allais Paradox, discovered by economist Maurice Allais. The mathematically consistent choices are either A and C together, or B and D together. However, many people choose A and D, which violates expected utility theory. We also tested whether making text harder to read affects people's choices.
